title: 105_s494
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and it involves prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" introduces copayments for health care services for prisoners, with definitions provided for terms like account, Director, health care provider, and health care visit. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines terms like health care visit, prisoner, and qualified health care visit. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines a qualified health care visit as any health care visit except those conducted during incarceration intake, annual examinations, emergency visits, immunizations, or initiated by Bureau of Prisons staff. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" exempts copayments for health care services for prisoners who are under 18, pregnant, seriously mentally ill, permanently disabled, receive immunizations, initiated by Bureau of Prisons staff, or referred by a prison official. The Director will assess and collect fees for health care services for prisoners, including copayments of $3 to $5 for each visit and up to $5 for prescription medications and specific health care visits. The Director will assess and collect fees for health care services for prisoners, including copayments for visits and prescription medications, as well as fees for visits resulting from injuries inflicted by another prisoner. Fees will be collected from the prisoner receiving the services. The Director will assess and collect fees for health care services for prisoners, including copayments for visits and prescription medications. Fees will be collected from the appropriate account on the date of the qualified health care visit or through an installment payment plan if the account balance is insufficient. The Director will establish an installment payment plan for prisoners to pay fees for health care services. Treatment cannot be refused due to financial reasons, and collected amounts will be deposited in the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director will establish an installment payment plan for prisoners to pay fees for health care services, with amounts collected deposited in the Crime Victims' Fund. Reports to Congress on amounts collected and effects of implementation will be submitted annually. Reports to Congress on amounts collected and effects of implementation will be submitted annually, including an analysis of the effects on health care visits by prisoners. Prisoners will be required to make copayments for health care services, with amounts collected deposited in the Crime Victims' Fund. Annual reports to Congress will include information on amounts collected and the impact of the copayments on health care visits by prisoners.
